awd_titl_txt: NSF/ENG/ECCS-BSF: Collaborative Research: Foundations of secure multi-agent networked systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research project is to develop a new framework for the design of secure multi-agent systems along with the tools necessary for their analysis. The rapid pace of innovation in the areas of control theory, computation, and communication is leading the way for a new class of networked systems characterized by their complex interconnections, diversity of components, and interactions with the physical world. The potential benefits of these networked systems from environmental, economic, and social perspectives are however limited by the ability to secure them. There are currently many efforts under way to address the underlying security issues by ways of developing secure communication protocols and procedures. The PIs take a different point of view here: instead of developing methods to secure existing systems, they develop methods to design systems that are inherently secure and embedded with breach detection mechanisms. The PIs thus expand the secure-by-design philosophy popular in software engineering to the design of networked dynamical systems. In terms of applications, the proposed research program will significantly push forward the frontiers of secure design of cyber-physical systems, furthering their use across many domains including critical infrastructures such as transportation networks, power generation and distribution networks, water and gas distribution networks. The PIs will also contribute to educational outreach by developing new interactive modules, focusing on security issues of CPS for high school students, and mentoring graduate and undergraduate students.

The proposed program is built upon three overarching principles: (i) control the information given to the agents, (ii) embed the agents with hidden security measures, and (iii) make the dynamics robust and resilient. More specifically, for the first principle, the PIs propose to establish a theoretical framework with novel design methodologies that can localize and encode both information and objectives for the agents. For the second principle, the PIs propose to embed the networked system with security measures that allow to detect easily tampering with large signals and its effect on the agents. These security measures can be certain functions that are designed to maintain invariant values over time and are locally computable by the agents. For the third principle, the PIs propose to leverage robust control theory for dealing with small attack injections, and moreover, introduce a novel controllability notion with provable guarantees on state attack recovery. In terms of intellectual merit, the proposed program will unify and exploit research in mathematics, namely integrating the study of symmetries in dynamical systems, completely integrable systems, and Hamiltonian dynamics, with engineering tools to develop methods to detect and foil attacks on a system. As such, it will establish new and deepen existing connections between mathematics, especially geometry and dynamical systems, and the study of cyber-physical systems. The project will be carried out in collaboration with Professor Daniel Zelazo of the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa, Israel.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The development of network-enabled systems is creating new opportunities for integrating disconnected systems. These systems, however, come with new challenges associated with their secure and resilient operation in the face of network-level faults, or even malicious actors intentionally aiming to disrupt their functionality. In this research project, we establish new methods for designing secure multi-agent systems and tools necessary for analyzing these systems. We present below a summary of major outcomes on multiple research topics achieved during the award period:

1. On network resilience: An inherent challenge in problems related to network resilience stems from their combinatorial nature. To wit, losing or adding communication links can be viewed as binary operations, which do not fit well within the framework of robust control theory. In this project, we have developed a new toolbox, which goes by translating these network resilience problems into max-flow problems on appropriately defined graphs. Based on these translations, we have then provided efficient algorithms that solve the problems in polynomial time.

2. On distributed computation: We have developed a novel secure-by-design protocol for distributed computation. The idea behind is to enable sequential updates of relatively small networks of agents to perform information exchange and computations; small networks are by nature more resilient and secure than larger ones. We have established new method for co-designing the structures of the small networks, the information processing among these small networks, and the order of the sequential updates by which all computational entities in the network will be able to accomplish their computational tasks in a secure and efficient way.

3. On global synchronization: Clock-synchronization over a distributed network finds many applications in cyber-physical systems. The problem we have addressed is about codesigning information flow topologies and decentralized control laws so that global synchronization can be achieved over the entire network. Many existing works have focused on special classes of network topologies to keep the analyses tractable. Also, there are several issues in those existing resetting algorithms; some algorithms assume that individual agents need to know, a priori, the size of the network and others are not scalable. In this project, we have resolved all the issues at a time. Specifically, we have proposed several stochastic resetting algorithms whereby all agents in the network can reach global synchronization almost surely as long as the underlying network topology is rooted connected. Furthermore, these newly proposed algorithms are robust against small perturbations, which can be viewed as small injection attacks.   

4. On distributed parameter estimation: One of the cornerstones of adaptive and learning based controllers is their ability to achieve fast and robust real-time parameter estimation. Many existing works deal with the problem of parameter estimation only for single agents or for networks characterized by undirected connected graphs (i.e., the communications links are reciprocal). The literature is sparse on the case where the network topologies are represented by directed graphs. In this project, we have succeeded in extending the so-called cooperative persistent exciting (PE) condition for connected undirected graphs to what we called "generalized cooperative PE condition" for arbitrary weakly connected directed graphs. More specifically, we have shown that this generalized condition is necessary and sufficient for uniform exponential stability of a class of gradient-based cooperative estimation dynamics.

5. On graph balancing: The problem of graph balancing is about assigning (nonnegative) weights to the directed edges of the graph so that the incoming flow is equal to the outgoing flow at every node. Graph balancing finds a host of applications in engineering and applied sciences, including the study of flocking behaviors, sensor networks, and distributed estimation. While balancing with real numbers is acceptable in some scenarios, others such as traffic management and fractional packing require integer balancing. Moreover, integer balancing is insensitive to small signal injections and, hence, much more robust against attacks compared to real balancing. In this project, we have established new results and algorithms that can translate real solutions of graph balancing to integers ones.
